Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Model-Based RSA for Cementless Tapered Wedge Femoral Stem

Background: This study evaluates the accuracy and clinical precision of model-based radiostereometric analysis (RSA) compared to marker-based RSA for measuring femoral stem rotation in total hip arthroplasty (THA).

Methods: In this randomised controlled trial, participants were patients undergoing THA with cementless tapered wedge femoral stems. The trial was conducted at a single orthopedic center. Participants were randomly assigned to either model-based RSA or marker-based RSA using computer-generated random numbers, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes. The primary outcome was the accuracy of RSA measurements, assessed using a phantom model with micromanipulators for controlled translation and rotation. Clinical precision was evaluated through double examinations of 24 patients. Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Results: A total of 24 patients were randomised, with 12 in each group. The accuracy of model-based RSA was 0.03 mm for subsidence and 0.39° for rotation, while marker-based RSA showed 0.06 mm and 0.18°, respectively. Clinical precision for model-based RSA was 0.14 mm for subsidence and 0.79° for rotation. No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: Model-based RSA demonstrated acceptable clinical precision, though its accuracy for rotation was slightly lower than marker-based RSA. It may be suitable for clinical trials of cementless tapered wedge femoral stem designs.
